subject: Re: Digest Number 1845
msgSnippet: ... Bob, While I don t agree with you 100% on Test First being THE solution, or THE right approach in ALL cases, I am definitely more in your camp than not.
messageBody:
> I wear a green wrist band that says "Test First". It is a symbol of
> my commitment to this minmium level of professional ethics. I WILL
> TEST MY CODE.

Bob,

While I don't agree with you 100% on Test First being THE solution, or
THE right approach in ALL cases, I am definitely more in your camp
than not.

When Roongko and I were at SunLabs, we headed a research project
called ADL (Assertion Definition Language) that was close in spirit to
test first: designers/developers would write the spec for the code
before writing it. The spec included both syntax (e.g. the method
signature) as well as semantics (what the method was supposed to do in
terms of assertions (the A in ADL) - for example: if X < 0 throw
InvalidArgumentException)).

The spec would serve as a guide for the developers: "I have to write
code that throws an InvalidArgumentException when X is less than 0".

The spec was also used to automatically generate tests that would
validate the specified behavior (e.g. pass -1 and check to see if the
InvalidArgumentException is thrown).

Not exactly test first, but the same basic idea: the code was not
"done" until the tests (generated directly from the spec therefore
in-sync with the spec) passed.

The system worked just fine, but there was a big problem. Most
developers did not want to write specs first. Let me be more
specific: some of them did not want to, others could not do it. Some
developers, including some very good ones, are not wired to think test
first. They could do it, but they would not be very effective at it -
like asking a left-handed person to write with their write hand.

Now, we could fire all people who refuse to, or are not good at test
first, but I don't think that will work. Over the years, and by
looking at the way the world works (which I know is far from ideal), I
have come to the conclusion that trying to globally change some
behaviors (even when the new behavior is so obviously best for
everyone (think smoking, eating junk, ..., not writing tests before
writing your code)) is a noble, but pointless pursuit. Some people
are going to be easily changed (the test infected ones in our
discussions - say ~30%), others might change with some effort and over
time - say another ~30%, but many are not going to be changed.

Let me attempt a simple analogy...

We all know that a bad diet leads to cholesterol and heart-disease.
Ideally all people should clean-up their diet and start exercising
regularly, but we know that's not going to happen, or happen fast
enough to save some lives. Cholesterol reducing drugs could be seen
as an excuse to not control diet and exercise (the way you say that
some tools could be used by developers as an excuse to not write
tests) but I am sure you would not withold them from people who are
not willing to be virtuous and change their ways. The goal is to
lower cholesterol and for most people the best approach is to clean-up
their diet AND take the drugs. Over-time they may get off the drugs,
but diet and exercise alone are simply not sufficient for a lot of people.

Similarly, when it comes to developing code I agree with you 100% that
developers should take responsibility for unit testing their own code
(although I don't feel as strong as you do about test *first*, testing
and testing well is what's most important to me).

And I believe that the most effective way to get developers to test
their code is to give them tools (JUnit is one, Agitator is another)
to make them as efficient and as effective as possible. To me, the
desirable end result is well designed, well tested, well understood
code using whatever methodology, technology, and tools are available
and work best for the code and the people in question.

>My problem is that I just don't know if the
>Agitation features of Agitar are really particularly useful.

I don't know how to respond to that except to, perhaps, schedule a
couple of days working *together* on real code to show you all the
benefits that you get from agitation. For example, do you know that
you can use Agitator in a test-first way? Again, we did not wake up
one morning looking for a problem to solve with our technology. I
believe that the core ideas behind agitation are not only useful, but
indispensable.

> Moreover I fear a tool that can figure out tests for you may give
> developers an excuse not to write their own tests;

Ah, you are missing one VERY CRITICAL point here. Unlike other test
automation products, Agitator does not "figure out" tests for you.
That's a key concept behind the agitation - without developer
intervention all you could test is that the code does what the code
does - we don't do that. Instead, we help you analyze the code by
showing you how it behaves, but without developer interaction, and
without a developer looking at observations and promoting them to
assertions, or adding their own assertions there are NO TESTS and no
test points. Please refer to my spreadsheet analogy in another post -
think of Agitator as a tool to accelerate, amplify, and add depth to
your testing effort (even your test-first efforts).

>especially if it
> is marketed to managers and developers as a way to reduce unit test
> writing time.

I don't believe that unit test *writing* *time* is the right thing to
look at. Using that time effectively is most important. Sometimes
using JUnit is the most effective way to test (e.g. when you have a
very specific sequence of operations in mind (as you mention in your
examples). Other times, using Agitator is the most effective way to
test (e.g. when you want to specify and test a class or method
invariant with a lot of valid and invalid inputs).

I believe that the most effective use of testing time *must* include a
tool like Agitator to help developers think about, discover, analyze,
all the possible behaviors of their code and generate powerful and
broad (data-driven) regression tests to complement more specific JUnit
tests when they exists.

OK, my word-count for the day is up. I hope that someone other than
the two of us reads these posts (feel free to chime in) otherwise we
might as well continue this conversation over a couple of beers :-).

Alberto (Test-first, test-during, test soon after, but please test!)










--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Robert Martin <UncleBob@...> wrote:
>
>
> On May 31, 2006, at 3:15 AM, junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:
>
> > Date: Tue May 30, 2006 11:44 am (PDT)
> > From: "albsavoia" albsavoia@...
> > Subject: JUnit *AND* Agitator
> >
> > Hi Bob,
> >
> > I appreciate your participation and opinions on this topic.
>
> Hello Alberto, great to talk with you.
> > Questions, discussions, and constructive criticism will help all of us
> > learn more about the problems and challenges of testing and how to
> > address them.
> >
> > So let me start :-). I will start not by talking about Agitator, but
> > about a more general issue: is there a problem with unit testing that
> > needs solving?
> >
> > You write:
> >
> >> The bottom line is that this is a very interesting product that
> >> appears to me to be looking for a problem to solve.
> >
> > I believe that there's a HUGE and GROWING problem to solve. My
> > co-founder (Dr. Roongko Doong, another person who is as passionate
> > about advancing the state-of-the-art in test automation for 15+
> > years), started Agitar not because we were looking for something to
> > do, or make a quick buck (quite the contrary, in 2002 when we started
> > Agitar I was Senior Director of Software Engineering at Google - if
> > all I cared about was money I would have stayed put :-)).
>
> Let me be clear. There was an old joke in the '60s about the Laser
> being a solution in search of a problem. I was making an oblique
> reference to that old joke, and not a snide remark about
> commercialism. I think the agitation technology is very cool. I'm
> just wondering what problem it solves.
>
> I agree with you that there is a huge and growing problem in software
> quality, and that test automation is the solution to that problem.
> I'm just perplexed about how Agitar addresses that issue.
>
> > We started
> > Agitar to solve what I believe is one of the biggest problems in
> > software development, and one that we are very passionate about:
> > getting developers to think about and do testing DURING development -
> > so they can address defects and design problems with maximum
> > efficiency and minimum impact. As opposed to the more traditional
> > "throw the code over the wall to QA" model.
>
> I completely agree that the over-the-wall method is broken. I think
> it's broken for many reasons.
>
> 1. Tests are done at the end of the schedule when there's no time
> left (because all the slack has been eaten up by the developers.)
>
> 2. Manual tests are very costly, time consuming, and error prone;
> especially when they come at the end and are under schedule pressure.
>
> 3. Tests that come at the end are based on the *current* execution of
> the program rather than on the true requirements. This is a bizarre
> break in encapsulation which tends to let the implementation drive
> the requirements.
>
> > My experience at Google, where with others I championed the
> > introduction of JUnit and the idea of developer testing was very
> > revealing. Admittedly, Google is a way off the chart in terms of
> > programming talent,
>
> And way off the charts in assisting repressive nations.
>
> > but in the last 4 years I confirmed the very same
> > findings with 100s of other people and software organizations that
> > also introduced, or tried to introduce, developer/unit testing:
> >
> > Here are some of the key things I discovered:
> >
> > 1) On average, approximately only 30% of developers who are introduced
> > to xUnit/developer-testing/TDD become test-infected (i.e. the will
> > continue to do unit testing even if they are not asked to). The other
> > 70% will go back to their "old-ways". Why is that? My next points
> > sheds some light.
> >
> > 2) Most developer complained that in order to get decent coverage (say
> > 80-90%) they have to write 3-4 lines of JUnit code for every line of
> > Java. They wanted some way to automate the most mundane parts of the
> > testing effort and retain control of the areas that require human
> > intelligence, insight, domain-knowledge, and creativity.
> >
> > 3) Most of the unit tests that actually get written cover only the
> > normal/"happy" path. They assume the best of all possible world; that
> > they would never be passed bad parameters, that all strings would be
> > nice ASCII code and never exceed some magic length, that all objects
> > will be well formed and in the state they were expecting, etc.
> > Needless to say, this is not sufficient for most industrial
> > applications, especially if they have to survive in hostile
> > environments where hackers look for every possible deficiency in the
> > system, or when your colleagues assume that you are going to handle
> > those null pointers so he does not have to worry about them. On the
> > other hand, if you want to cover all those contingencies testing
> > becomes a combinatorial problem and it's hard for developers to
> > conceive of and test for everything that should be tested for.
> >
> > 4) If testing a particular piece of code was too complicated (lots of
> > dependencies, complicated set-up, lots of things to mock, etc.) the
> > tests were skipped. This is human nature. Ideally people would look
> > at code that's difficult to test and think re-factoring and (re)design
> > for testability but most people are not there yet.
> >
> > 5) Test maintenance was as time consuming as code maintenance. If
> > there's anything that most developers disliked more than writing lots
> > of test code by hand, was maintaining that code. One of the most
> > common unit test maintenance patterns is: delete or comment-out
> > failing tests.
>
> My solution to all these "problems" is to re-educate the developers
> and fire the ones who don't realize that they can't release untested
> code. This seems to me to be a matter of professional ethics. I
> have no sympathy for whining software developers who don't want to
> write tests. What they are really whining about is that they don't
> want to be responsible for making their code work.
>
> Writing tests first (i.e. true TDD) solves most of the problems
> mentioned above except the discipline problem. Pink slips solve that
> problem. (I'm dead serious about this. You don't test, you don't
> work. Period.)
>
> Using TDD you can't write production code unless you write a failing
> unit test first. Thus you will get very high coverage (80-90), and
> you won't write code that's hard to test, because you write the tests
> first.
>
> Refactoring solves the test maintenance problem. Tests are not
> second class citizens. They have to be kept to the same standard of
> cleanliness and design as production code. Therefore we refactor
> them to keep them easy to modify.
> >
> > So, for someone who believes that developer/unit testing is the right
> > thing to do - one of the MOST important things to do and do WELL - I
> > saw a VERY big and VERY definite problem. Namely: Most developers
> > want and need help with their testing effort. Without some help and
> > automation they will either give up on developer/unit testing or, even
> > worse because it gives a false sense of security, write some trivial
> > "happy-path" tests that pass too easily and fail to cover some
> > critical conditions.
>
> Again, developers who have the attitude that it is OK to give up on
> testing need their attitude readjusted -- and fast! I have no
> problem with tools to help with this; but the first problem to solve
> is the attitude problem.
>
> Also, one of my problems with the Agitar tool is that it can't seem
> to see very far into a function. Therefore the observations it makes
> are naive, thus possibly reinforcing the "false sense of security"
> you talked about.
>
> > Note that I am not in favor of complete
> > automation (press a button get some passing tests) unless you need
> > some quick change detector. I want Agitator to do for software
> > developers what spreadsheets have done for accountants and business
> > people: raise the level of abstraction, allow the user to focus on the
> > important things that require their intelligence and understanding
> > (e.g. formulae in spreadsheets, test data/assertions in Agitator),
> > provide a number of other related utilities (e.g. graphs in
> > spreadsheets, code coverage and code rules and dashboard reports in
> > Agitator).
>
> I like the code coverage aspects of Agitar. Some of the graphs and
> charts are very useful. I have no problems with them at all.
> >
> > We could argue whether Agitator helps with some of the problems (I
> > believe it does since it was designed to address them specifically),
> > but I don't think we can argue that there is no problem to be solved
> > when it comes to developer testing. Until most developers and
> > software development organizations practice thorough unit testing on a
> > consistent basis, we have a problem.
>
> Agreed. And tool support is important. Education is even more
> important. There is a minimum level of professional ethics involved
> here, and every developer needs to learn it.
>
> I wear a green wrist band that says "Test First". It is a symbol of
> my commitment to this minmium level of professional ethics. I WILL
> TEST MY CODE.
> >
> > Without JUnit we would not be where we are today. A 30% test
> > infection rate is a huge step from what it was before (i.e. ~0%). But
> > I refuse believe that we cannot augment and provide developers with
> > other tools beyond JUnit, and that we are stuck at 30% test infected.
>
> I agree. And I think JUnit was partially responsible for this.
> However I also think that the revolution would have happened without
> the tool -- causing the tool to be written anyway.
> >
> > There's work we all have left to do.
> >
> > People like you are helping our common cause doing what you do best
> > and, presumably, like to do best: training, coaching, mentoring,
> > educating, writing, etc.
> >
> > Me? I am a software tool maker. That's what I do best, and that's
> > what I like to do. That's the best way I can help the cause. I
> > believe that tools are critical to progress, and that the right tools
> > will enable the right behavior. Anyone who knows me, or has talked
> > with me for just a few minutes, knows how passionate I am about
> > solving this problem (if we agree that there is a problem :-)) and I
> > also would like to think that in addition to my passion, I bring some
> > unique experience, skills, and vision to the table.
>
> And I appreciate that! I think we need more and better tools for
> software development. My problem is that I just don't know if the
> Agitation features of Agitar are really particularly useful.
> Moreover I fear a tool that can figure out tests for you may give
> developers an excuse not to write their own tests; especially if it
> is marketed to managers and developers as a way to reduce unit test
> writing time.
>
